member.name: T:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher
member.summary: Enumerates devices dynamically, so that the app receives notifications if devices are added, removed, or changed after the initial enumeration is complete.

member.name: P:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Status
member.summary: The status of the DeviceWatcher.

member.name: M:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Start
member.summary: Starts a search for devices, and subscribes to device enumeration events.

member.name: M:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Stop
member.summary: Stop raising the events that add, update and remove enumeration results.

member.name: E:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Added
member.summary: Event that is raised when a device is added to the collection enumerated by the DeviceWatcher.

member.name: E:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Updated
member.summary: Event that is raised when a device is updated in the collection of enumerated devices.

member.name: E:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Removed
member.summary: Event that is raised when a device is removed from the collection of enumerated devices.

member.name: E:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.EnumerationCompleted
member.summary: Event that is raised when the enumeration of devices completes.

member.name: E:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcher.Stopped
member.summary: Event that is raised when the enumeration operation has been stopped.

member.name: T:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus
member.summary: Describes the state of a DeviceWatcher object.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.Created
member.summary: This is the initial state of a Watcher object. During this state clients can register event handlers.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.Started
member.summary: The watcher transitions to the Started state once Start is called. The watcher is enumerating the initial collection. Note that during this enumeration phase it is possible to receive Updated and Removed notifications but only to items that have already been Added.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.EnumerationCompleted
member.summary: The watcher has completed enumerating the initial collection. Items can still be added, updated or removed from the collection.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.Stopping
member.summary: The client has called Stop and the watcher is still in the process of stopping. Events may still be raised.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.Stopped
member.summary: The client has called Stop and the watcher has completed all outstanding events. No further events will be raised.

member.name: F:Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceWatcherStatus.Aborted
member.summary: The watcher has aborted operation. No subsequent events will be raised.

Validate if a given permission was granted to the app and if not, request it to the user.
This operation is not cancellable. This should not be invoked directly from the application code. You should use the extension methods in PermissionsServiceExtensions.

member.name: T:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayBrightnessOverrideOptions
member.summary: Describes the options that modify the brightness level of the screen during the override session. When UseDimmedPolicyWhenBatteryIsLow is set, it reduces the specified override brightness level in order to conserve battery if the device battery is low during the override session. For example, if the override brightness level is set to 100% and UseDimmedPolicyWhenBatteryIsLow is set, the screen will dim to 70% instead.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayBrightnessOverrideOptions.None
member.summary: Screen display stays at the specified override brightness level when the device battery is low.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayBrightnessOverrideOptions.UseDimmedPolicyWhenBatteryIsLow
member.summary: Screen display dims when the device battery is low and a brightness override session is running.

member.name: T:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations
member.summary: Describes the orientation of a rectangular monitor.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations.None
member.summary: No display orientation is specified.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations.Landscape
member.summary: Specifies that the monitor is oriented in landscape mode where the width of the display viewing area is greater than the height.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations.Portrait
member.summary: Specifies that the monitor rotated 90 degrees in the clockwise direction to orient the display in portrait mode where the height of the display viewing area is greater than the width.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations.LandscapeFlipped
member.summary: Specifies that the monitor rotated another 90 degrees in the clockwise direction (to equal 180 degrees) to orient the display in landscape mode where the width of the display viewing area is greater than the height. This landscape mode is flipped 180 degrees from the **Landscape** mode.

member.name: F:Windows.Graphics.Display.DisplayOrientations.PortraitFlipped
member.summary: Specifies that the monitor rotated another 90 degrees in the clockwise direction (to equal 270 degrees) to orient the display in portrait mode where the height of the display viewing area is greater than the width. This portrait mode is flipped 180 degrees from the **Portrait** mode.

member.name: M:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkInformation.OnDelayedNetworkStatusChanged

member.name: T:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel
member.summary: Defines the level of connectivity currently available.

member.name: F:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.None
member.summary: No connectivity.

member.name: F:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.LocalAccess
member.summary: Local network access only.

member.name: F:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.ConstrainedInternetAccess
member.summary: Limited internet access.
member.remarks: This value indicates captive portal connectivity, where local access to a web portal is provided, but access to the Internet requires that specific credentials are provided via the portal. This level of connectivity is generally encountered when using connections hosted in public locations(for example, coffee shops and book stores).

member.name: F:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.InternetAccess
member.summary: Local and Internet access.

member.name: F:Windows.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkCostType.Variable

member.summary: The file update was not fully completed and should be retried.

member.summary: The file update was completed successfully.

member.summary: User input (like credentials) is needed to update the file.

member.name: F:Windows.Storage.Provider.FileUpdateStatus.CurrentlyUnavailable
member.summary: The remote version of the file was not updated because the storage location wasn't available. The file remains valid and subsequent updates to the file may succeed.

member.name: F:Windows.Storage.Provider.FileUpdateStatus.Failed
member.summary: The file is now invalid and can't be updated now or in the future. For example, this could occur if the remote version of the file was deleted.

member.name: F:Windows.Storage.Provider.FileUpdateStatus.CompleteAndRenamed
member.summary: The file update was completed successfully and the file has been renamed. For example, this could occur if the user chose to save their changes under a different file name because of conflicting changes made to the remote version of the file.

member.summary: Initiates updates for the specified file. This method contacts the app that provided the file to perform the updates.

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Core.CoreDispatcher
member.summary: Defines a priority-based UI Thread scheduler.
member.remarks:
This implementation is based on the fact that the native queue will only contain one instance of the callback for the current core dispatcher.
This gives the native events, such as touch, the priority over managed-side queued events, and will allow a properly prioritized processing of idle events.

member.summary: Defines a event raise method.

The source of the event raise
The args used to raise the event

member.name: T:Windows.UI.Core.WeakEventHelper.GenericEventHandler
member.summary: An abstract handler to be called when raising the weak event.
member.param: The source of the event
The args of the event, which must match the explicit cast performed in the matching instance.

member.name: M:Windows.UI.Core.WeakEventHelper.RegisterEvent(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Windows.UI.Core.WeakEventHelper.GenericEventHandler},System.Delegate,Windows.UI.Core.WeakEventHelper.EventRaiseHandler)
member.summary: Provides a bi-directional weak event handler management.
member.param: A list of registrations to manage
The actual handler to execute.
The delegate used to raise if it has not been collected.
member.returns: A disposable that keeps the registration alive.
member.remarks:
The bi-directional relation is defined by the fact that both the source and the target are weak. The source must be kept alive by another longer-lived reference, and the target is kept alive by the return disposable.
If the returned disposable is collected, the handler will also be collected. Conversely, if the is collected raising the event will produce nothing.

member.name: P:Windows.UI.ViewManagement.ApplicationView.TrueVisibleBounds
member.summary:
All other platforms: equivalent to .
Android: returns the visible bounds taking the status bar into account. The status bar is not removed from on Android when it's opaque, on the grounds that the root managed view is already arranged below the status bar in y-direction by default (unlike iOS), but in some cases the correct total height is needed, hence this property.

member.name: T:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1
member.summary: Provides a resource pool that enables reusing instances of type .

remarks.para: Renting and returning buffers with an can increase performance in situations where arrays are created and destroyed frequently, resulting in significant memory pressure on the garbage collector.
This class is thread-safe. All members may be used by multiple threads concurrently.

member.name: F:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.s_sharedInstance
member.summary: The lazily-initialized shared pool instance.

member.name: P:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Shared
member.summary: Retrieves a shared instance.
member.remarks: The shared pool provides a default implementation of that's intended for general applicability. It maintains arrays of multiple sizes, and may hand back a larger array than was actually requested, but will never hand back a smaller array than was requested. Renting a buffer from it with will result in an existing buffer being taken from the pool if an appropriate buffer is available or in a new buffer being allocated if one is not available.

member.name: M:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.EnsureSharedCreated
member.summary: Ensures that has been initialized to a pool and returns it.

member.name: M:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Create
member.summary: Creates a new instance using default configuration options.
member.returns: A new instance.

member.name: M:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Create(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance using custom configuration options.
member.param: The maximum length of array instances that may be stored in the pool.
The maximum number of array instances that may be stored in each bucket in the pool. The pool groups arrays of similar lengths into buckets for faster access.
member.returns: A new instance with the specified configuration options.
member.remarks: The created pool will group arrays into buckets, with no more than in each bucket and with those arrays not exceeding in length.

member.summary: The default maximum length of each array in the pool.

member.summary: The default maximum number of arrays per bucket that are available for rent when using automatic memory management.

member.summary: The default maximum number of arrays per bucket that are available for rent.

member.summary: Determines if automatic memory management can be used.

member.summary: Determines if automatic memory management is enabled

member.summary: Determines if GC trim callback has been registerd if non-zero

member.summary: Current platform features provider

member.name: P:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Id
member.summary: Gets an ID for the pool to use with events.

member.name: M:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Rent(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a buffer that is at least the requested length.
member.param: The minimum length of the array needed.
member.returns: An that is at least in length.
member.remarks: This buffer is loaned to the caller and should be returned to the same pool via so that it may be reused in subsequent usage of . It is not a fatal error to not return a rented buffer, but failure to do so may lead to decreased application performance, as the pool may need to create a new buffer to replace the one lost.

member.name: M:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Return(`0[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns to the pool an array that was previously obtained via on the same instance.
member.param: The buffer previously obtained from to return to the pool.

If true and if the pool will store the buffer to enable subsequent reuse, will clear of its contents so that a subsequent consumer via will not see the previous consumer's content. If false or if the pool will release the buffer, the array's contents are left unchanged.
member.remarks: Once a buffer has been returned to the pool, the caller gives up all ownership of the buffer and must not use it. The reference returned from a given call to must only be returned via once. The default may hold onto the returned buffer in order to rent it again, or it may release the returned buffer if it's determined that the pool already has enough buffers stored.

member.name: T:Uno.Buffers.ArrayPool`1.Bucket

member.summary: Attempts to return the buffer to the bucket. If successful, the buffer will be stored in the bucket and true will be returned; otherwise, the buffer won't be stored, and false will be returned.

member.name: T:Uno.UI.Core.KeyboardStateTracker
member.summary: Tracks keyboard key state.
member.remarks: The behavior is based on description in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.core.corevirtualkeystates. In UWP/WinUI, every key has a locked state (not only Caps Lock, etc.). The sequence of states is as follows: (None) -> (Down) -> (None) -> (Down + Locked) -> (None + Locked) -> (Down) -> (None) -> etc.

member.summary: Start the count at 1, this ensures the deferral won't be completed until all subscribers to the corresponding event have had a chance to take out a deferral object.

member.name: M:Uno.Helpers.DeferralManager`1.EventRaiseCompleted
member.summary: This marks the deferral as ready for completion. Must be called after the related event finished invoking. In case the operation is not deferred, it will also synchronously raise the Completed event.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the deferral completed synchronously.

member.name: T:Uno.Helpers.StartStopEventWrapper`1
member.summary: Creates a wrapper around an event, which needs to be synchronized and needs to run an action when first subscriber is added and when last subscriber is removed. The operations executed when first subscriber is added and last subscriber is removed will execute within a synchronization lock, so please avoid blocking within the actions.

member.name: M:Uno.Helpers.StartStopEventWrapper`1.#ctor(System.Action,System.Action,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of start-stop event wrapper.
member.param: Action to run when first subscriber is added. This will run within a synchronization lock so it should not involve blocking operations.
Action to run when last subscriber is removed. This will run within a synchronization lock so it should not involve blocking operations.
Optional shared object to lock on (when multiple events rely on the same native platform operation.

member.summary: Determines if automatic memory management is used for the ArrayPool.

WARNING: Altering this setting may degrade the performance of the application significantly. This value is captured automatically after App(), any subsequent change is ignored.
Automatic memory management uses to determine the acceptable memory consumption for pools, and uses GC triggers to reduce the pressure.

member.name: P:Uno.WinRTFeatureConfiguration.GestureRecognizer.InterpretMouseLeftLongPressAsRightTap
member.summary: Determines if unlike UWP, long press on the left button of a mouse should be interpreted as a right tap. This is useful as the right button is commonly used by Android devices for back navigation. Using a long press with left button will be more intuitive for Android's users. Note that a long press on the right button is usually not used for back navigation, and will always be interpreted as a right tap no matter the value of this flag.

member.name: P:Uno.WinRTFeatureConfiguration.GestureRecognizer.ShouldProvideHapticFeedback

member.name: P:Uno.WinRTFeatureConfiguration.MessageDialog.UseNativeDialog

member.name: P:Uno.WinRTFeatureConfiguration.MessageDialog.StyleOverride
